items.title: NCORES Related Crash on Windows
items.body:
Hi,

It's not totally clear to me why but this line causes a crash on a Windows machine with 64 or more cores:
https://github.com/KaveIO/PhiK/blob/1ae2642579f5716a6b1f1c896c2271b741cbbcb7/python/phik/phik.py#L146

I believe it is related to this long-present bug in Python:
https://bugs.python.org/issue26903

I'd suggest allowing the NCORES to be overridden with an environment variable or manually decreasing the value when it is >=64 on a Windows machine.

Thanks

items.title: Support for PySpark
items.body: Is there any roadmap to be able to run this library on PySpark?  We run this library on data frames with thousands of columns and the run time is very slow.

items.title: Handling categorical variables with many unique values
items.body:
First, thanks for this package; it's great that cutting-edge statistical research can be put into practice so promptly and easily.

I have a dataset with millions of rows and categorical variables with tens of thousands of unique values.  When I run `phik_matrix()` on it, I get a warning like this:
```UserWarning: The number of unique values of variable a is very large: 101. Are you sure this is not an interval variable? Analysis for pairs of variables including a might be slow.```

And it is indeed slow.  What's the best way to handle high-cardinality categoricals?  Downsample to less than 100 values?  Choose only rows with the most common 100 values?

items.title: Distance metric in UMAP
items.body: It would be interesting to see PhiK as a distance metric in UMAP (see https://github.com/lmcinnes/umap/issues/319). However, it requires a concise numba-enabled implementation in [distances.py](https://github.com/lmcinnes/umap/blob/master/umap/distances.py#L321)

items.title: Ordering of column names in correlation matrix
items.body:
The `df.phik_matrix()` returns the correlation matrix with the column names ordered. Pandas keeps the order identical to the input (e.g. [`df.corr('pearson')`](https://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/reference/api/pandas.DataFrame.corr.html])). 

I would propose to preserve the order as given in the dataframe. It is a simple preprocessing step to sort the columns if desired, for reversing we need to get the mapping from the original dataframe etc. This also allows for easier comparison with correlation matrices produces by pandas.
